Award.AwardTitle: Using Dark Matter Microhalos to Probe the Universe's First Second
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Adrienne Erickcek at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

The evolution of the Universe during its first second is unknown. While there is strong evidence that the Universe's first second included a period of accelerated expansion called inflation, we do know why inflation happened or why it ended. We also do not know how the Universe transitioned to a hot, radiation-dominated state after inflation. Furthermore, our ignorance of the dynamics of the early Universe severely limits our understanding of the origins of dark matter, which is a poorly understood source of mass that currently makes up about 25% of the Universe's energy density. Many proposed explanations for dark matter postulate that dark matter originated from the hot plasma that filled the Universe during its first second. Consequently, the evolution of the Universe during that time affects the relationship between the properties of the dark matter particle and amount of dark matter in the Universe. This project will enhance our understanding of inflation, the onset of radiation domination, and the origins of dark matter by using gamma-ray observations to constrain the abundance of the smallest gravitationally bound structures of dark matter.

The PI will engage undergraduate students, high school students, and the general public in the proposed investigation of dark matter microhalos. Undergraduate students will analyze simulations of microhalo formation, thereby learning data analysis techniques and scientific programming. They will also gain first-hand research experience, which will expose them to the excitement of STEM careers. A module on dark matter will be developed for high school students to give them the opportunity to analyze publically available kinematic data for dwarf spheroidal and spiral galaxies. The PI will then lead four professional development workshops at teacher conferences to train high school teachers to use this module in their physics courses. Finally, the PI will present her research at Morehead?s monthly Carolina Science Cafe, which provides the general public the opportunity to interact with a scientific researcher in an informal setting.

These small dark matter structures, called microhalos, grow from density perturbations that were generated during inflation on scales that are inaccessible by other cosmological observations. They also began to evolve during the Universe's first second, prior to the onset of nucleosynthesis. This project will extend the PI's earlier analyses of microhalos' capacity to probe the evolution of the early Universe to a wider range of dark matter particles and will use N-body simulations of small volumes at high redshifts to test these analytical predictions for the microhalo abundance. These simulations will also determine how the properties of the small-scale density perturbations affect the microhalos' internal structures. The PI will then calculate the expected gamma-ray emission from dark matter annihilation within these microhalos. The resulting constraints on the small-scale primordial density fluctuations and the onset of radiation domination will determine which inflationary models are compatible with thermal-relic dark matter and may break the degeneracy between the relic density of dark matter and the evolution of the early Universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the matter in the Universe is composed of dark matter: an unknown particle that has never been directly observed but whose gravitational influence is apparent throughout the cosmos.  Unfortunately, our ability to understand the origins of dark matter is severely hampered by our ignorance of the evolution of the Universe while dark matter was produced.  The investigation funded by this award aimed to use gamma-ray observations to probe the evolution of the Universe during its first second by constraining the abundance of the smallest gravitationally bound clumps of dark matter.  These dark matter microhalos contain information about the density fluctuations that seeded them and the Universe's expansion rate during their formation.  The absence of gamma-rays from dark matter-dominated systems limits the number of these microhalos because, in most theories of dark matter, dark matter particles annihilate each other when they collide, and these annihilations generate gamma-rays.  By concentrating the dark matter into relatively dense clumps, microhalos increase the collision rate between dark matter particles, thus boosting the annihilation rate.

 

There were two major prongs of this investigation.  First, we sought to determine how the evolution of the Universe during its first second affects the number density and internal structure of microhalos.  We determined that both an early-matter-dominated era (EMDE) and a period of kination (during which the Universe was dominated by a fast-rolling scalar field) enhance small-scale density fluctuations.  We used cosmological simulations to confirm that an EMDE radically enhances the abundance of microhalos.  These simulated microhalos contain copious amounts of substructure, which indicates that the earliest-forming microhalos survive as subhalos within later-forming microhalos.  We estimated the dark matter annihilation rate within these microhalos and found that it was high enough to rule out some dark matter production scenarios during an EMDE.  We also learned that the dark matter annihilation rate following an EMDE is highly sensitive to the size of the smallest dark matter halos, and we investigated how this minimum halo mass depends on properties of the dark matter particle.  In the process, we discovered that the dark matter does not cool as rapidly during an EMDE as it does while the Universe is radiation dominated.

 

Second, we investigated how dark matter halos can be used to probe the properties of the initial density fluctuations that seed their formation: halos form when regions of the Universe that contain slightly more matter than average undergo gravitational collapse.  These initial density fluctuations are thought to be generated during inflation, which was an instant of accelerated expansion in the very early Universe, and we can learn about inflation by studying the amplitudes of these fluctuations.  It had been theorized that an enhancement of small-scale inhomogeneity would result in the formation of ultracompact minihalos (UCMHs) 400,000 years after the end of inflation (corresponding to a redshift z=1000).  We numerically tested the UCMH hypothesis by simulating microhalo formation using initial conditions with enhanced fluctuations over a narrow range of scales (i.e. a spike in the power spectrum).  Our numerical simulations revealed that UCMHs do not have the steep density profile that was predicted by radial-infall theory.  We developed a model that predicts the density profiles of the halos that form from a spike in the primordial power spectrum based on the halos' formation times and used it to derive new bounds on the amplitude of a sharp spike in the primordial power spectrum.  By using all the halos that form from the spike instead of just the earliest forming halos, we were able to obtain stronger bounds than the old UCMH model yielded, in spite of the decreased annihilation rate within each microhalo due to the shallower density profile.  These new bounds will help us learn about the later stages of inflation.

 

Four graduate students and eight undergraduate students contributed to this investigation, gaining technical and research skills along the way.  Of the five undergraduates who have completed their degrees, two are currently enrolled in astrophysics Ph.D. programs, while the other three are pursuing science-related careers in industry and education.   The PI was also involved in several outreach activities during the duration of this award.  She hosted the July 2015 Carolina Science Cafe, a free monthly program designed to engage adults in an exploration of current science research.  The PI's presentation was titled "Big Bang 101," and it was attended by 127 people -- a record-setting attendance at a summer session.  The PI's "Astronomy on Tap" presentation on the beginning of the Universe drew a similarly large crowd.  The PI has also given five other outreach presentations to high school physics students, the Chapel Hill Astronomical and Observational Society, and as part of the "Adventures in Ideas" workshop series organized by the UNC Program in the Humanities and Human Values.
